Well, no. A $2.8bn deal ain't going to move the needle here.

BE

Quick bit of Kit Juckes.

BE

Theresa May has established herself very firmly as the front-runner in the contest to lead the Conservative party. Although she was a ‘Quiet Remainer’ she intends to respect the outcome of the referendum and begin the process of taking the UK out of the EU, albeit without rushing to trigger Article 50. This offers no respite from political and economic uncertainty in the months ahead and while sterling is currently recovering from the overnight slide, any bounce will be relatively short-lived. A move towards GBP/USD 1.20-1.25 over the medium term seems
appropriate, anything more still looks like an overshoot. Comparisons with 1985 are inevitably but not that relevant. GBP/USD was last below 1.30 in June 85, but it was on its way back up after the Volcker-Reagan induced dollar overshoot. GBP/USD recovered from 1.05 in February to reach 2 by 1991 as BOE rates rose sharply relative to Fed Funds.

11:11 am
BE

Is that it? Is it the May effect? Having a PM who's going to aim for an orderly exit, rather than one who's too much of a shambles not to blunder into a second referendum or a simple steamrolling over public opinion?

BE

I really don't like doing politics here, but some days it's unavoidable.

11:12 am
PM

Here's a lump of Barr

PM

Malcolm Barr, JPM

PM

On the one hand, we expect Mark Carney to project confidence that the MPC has a suite of tools with which it can ultimately attain its inflation objective. On the other, we expect the minutes and commentary from other MPC members to reflect concern that the growth impact of straightforward extensions of QE, as designed previously, will not be large. In our view, the key role of QE through gilt purchases at this point is not via the size of the quantum and the portfolio balance type effects. It is in signalling that there is a monetary backstop for fiscal expansion, such that any possible negative response in the gilt market reflecting a change in fiscal approach will be contained.

It will take time for changes in fiscal approach given the Brexit shock to be clear, given that an emergency budget does not look likely at this point. But the direction of travel is already becoming clear given statements from May, Osborne, and others. We do not believe it is the quantum of purchases that matters for the MPC at this point. To some extent the MPC will likely not want to encourage a view in markets that each deterioration in the data relative to forecast from here would automatically be met by simply by raising the quantum of purchases, as was the case during the prior two periods of QE. Indeed it might be more useful to suggest that QE was, at least in part, being calibrated with a view to ensuring gilt yields remained “low” and offering some soft guidance as to what “low” means.

11:13 am
PM

When QE was restarted back in October 2011, the MPC announced a £75bn increase taking the total up to £275bn, and consistent with a monthly pace of purchases running near £20bn a month. Given the above, we look for the MPC to announce a £75bn purchase program spread initially over a 6 month period. This would take the period of gilt purchases through both the Autumn statement and most likely through the 2017 budget presentation. This would be a somewhat slower pace of purchases, but extending for a longer period of time. A commitment to open-ended QE cannot be ruled out, but we think the MPC will stick with the prior approach.

We note that there has been a lot of talk of the Treasury supporting the Bank of England’s actions since the referendum result. If the QE program were to shift toward large quantities of purchasing private sector assets, it would need support from politicians. Of course, we face a difficulty that politics is in flux, but the BoE still has a government it can relate to and get permission to act from (right now, Cameron is still PM, Osborne still Chancellor). At this stage, we do not anticipate any large scale program of purchases of corporate bonds (the market is too small anyway), or financial sector debt, or equities. But it is not something we would rule out, either.

The bad news is dilution. Quite a lot of it.

BE

11:22 am
BE

Not priced yet.

BE

"likely to be well below our 523p/share NAV", says RBC. Well, yes. Probably. Given the current price is about two-thirds below that.

BE

. The equity is likely to be sold as a hedge by
buyers of the bonds. More positively, the dilution should be limited and this is a useful diversification of funding for Tullow; and, given that we believe that the
company is turning a corner any weakness today should be seen as an opportunity to buy the dollar-earner ahead of a material increase in production and free
cash flow in H2/16.
Duration: The diversification of the sources of capital trumps the dilution, in our view. Specifically we would highlight the duration of the ‘loan’ to 2021. We
believe that Tullow should be able to renegotiate a sizeable RBL at year-end 2016, but we would expect the facility to amortise relatively quickly (i.e. we do not
expect the company to negotiate a seven-year facility, like Lundin’s, that amortises over the final two years), therefore access to alternative sources of long-
term capital is welcome.

Working capital: In addition, the bond issue helps provide additional liquidity; Tullow’s $4.7bn of net debt at the end of June was below our expectations, but
we continue to anticipate a material negative swing in working capital, and the additional cash outflows for the Jubilee turret repair, plus the uncertain timing of
the insurance repayments, could make cash flows lumpy over the coming months.
Details: The Bonds will be issued at par and are expected to carry a coupon of between 5.9-6.6% per annum payable semi-annually in arrears on 12th January
and 12th July, with the first interest payment in January 2017. The Bonds will be convertible into fully paid ordinary shares at a price that is expected to be set
at a premium of between 30-35% above the VWAP on 6th July 2016. It is intended that an application will be made for the Bonds to be listed on a recognised
stock exchange prior to the first interest payment in January 2017.

11:23 am
BE

And note that it's a stopgap measure.

BE

To plug a funding gap. It doesn't take that much pressure off the longer term picture, which will probably involve asset sales (whenever possible).

BE

Rumours running for quite a long time that Tullow would perhaps sell its Uganda stake.

11:25 am
BE

Though that'd likely require Total to buy it, given the structure of the JV.

BE

Here's Deutsche.

BE

At the end of June 2016, Tullow reported net debt of $4.7bn and unutilised
debt capacity and free cash of c.$1.0bn. The first amortisation of its $3.5bn
Reserve Based Loan (RBL) is scheduled in October 2016, when commitments
will reduce to $3.25bn. Tullow plans to refinance the RBL in 2017 once the
TEN field is onstream, and with 6M of production history behind it, and before
any further amortisation. However, the reported production outages on its
flagship Jubilee field in Ghana (35.5% WI) are expected to have a short term
impact on liquidity (lost production, higher opex, additional capex) ahead of
insurance payments and resolution of the turret issues on the FPSO.

11:26 am
BE

We think that Tullow has therefore acted to plug the net gap of roughly $150m
in lost cash flow and $150m in higher costs over the next 12M by tapping the
cheapest form of capital available to it. As we argued in our recent Revisiting
the E&P sector report, the leveraged producers are focused on redressing the
imbalance between equity and credit. At current commodity prices, we expect
the highly geared E&P players to direct cash flows towards balance sheet
remediation rather than reinvestment; which we think benefits credit more
than equity investors. This is an attempt to rebalance that equation, whilst at
the same time broadening its investor base to an asset class often associated
with the E&P sector. We think the terms are relatively competitive as Tullow's
credit quality remains top tier due to its higher production volumes, stronger
liquidity, lower production costs and better hedging compared to the majority
of its European E&P peers.

BE

Our 270p TP is the product of our 360p risked NAV ($70/bbl LT, 10% WACC)
and target P/NAV of 0.75x. Tullow currently trades at ~0.65x P/NAV, a ~10%
discount to the European E&P average. Key downside risks are project delays /
cost overruns, adverse rulings in legal disputes and production outages on the
Jubilee FPSO. Key upside risks are for a swift end to the Jubilee FPSO turret
issue and/or valuation-enhancing divestments.

BE

"Key upside risks are for a swift end to the Jubilee FPSO turret issue" .... Okay, so perhaps we can't stop worrying about the swivel pipe on its floating thing.

11:33 am
BE

Melrose has announced it has reached an agreement with Nortek on the terms of a recommended proposed acquisition of Nortek by Melrose for $86 per share, equivalent to an enterprise value of ~£2.2bn. Melrose intends to finance the acquisition through the combination of a ~£1.655bn Rights Issue and new debt funding. The statement confirms the Board expects “The Acquisition will be significantly accretive to headline earnings per share in its first full financial year of ownership (2017) and thereafter”.

BE

 Nortek. Nortek is a diversified global manufacturer of air management, security, home automation and
ergonomic and productivity solutions. The business is listed on NASDAQ (under the symbol NTK). The
business has leading positions in air management with a comprehensive set of heating, air conditioning and
ventilation products for the repair, remodeling and new construction markets. Additionally the business has a
range of security and home automation, access control, residential audio visual, home integration and control,
power and energy management and ergonomic solutions which are sold into a range of markets. Over 90% of
Nortek’s revenues are in North America and product penetration is ~80% of US households.
 Transaction structure. Melrose has agreed to pay $86 per share which, given the existing Nortek debt structure, implies an enterprise value of ~£2.2bn. Melrose intends to finance the acquisition and associated transaction costs through a fully underwritten Rights Issue of ~£1.655bn (12 new shares at 95p for 1 existing share), new debt financing of ~£600m and ~£45m of existing Melrose cash. The Executive Directors will invest £17m, equal to ~1% of the issue, in addition to taking up their existing rights.
 Acquisition rationale. The Melrose Board sees Nortek as a “significant opportunity” to execute its ‘buy, improve, sell’ model. The statement outlines Nortek’s established positions in US construction, primarily residential but also commercial, a market projected to continue to grow but also a portfolio that could be improved and more focused on the opportunities. Melrose has also identified operational improvements as well as opportunities for additional investment at Nortek, both areas where Melrose management has a proven track record in delivering in order to improve the margin profile at acquired businesses. The operational improvements would be in addition to ongoing improvement programmes at Nortek. Melrose has arranged a new debt facility that is at a significantly lower interest rate than that currently being paid by Nortek on its existing debt.
 Shareholder acceptance. The Nortek Board recommends the offer to its shareholders. Certain stockholders representing 68.7% of the total share capital of Nortek have already entered into Tender and Support agreements effectively accepting the Melrose offer. The Merger Agreement provides that, should Nortek, prior to the Window Shop Deadline (6 August 2016), receive a Superior Proposal (being unsolicited and bona fide and in compliance with a non-solicit covenant) then, subject to, among other things, the ability of Melrose to match and amend its offer and the payment of a fee of $50.0 million by Nortek, Nortek may terminate the Merger Agreement. The acquisition is expected to complete in late August/early September 2016.
 Melrose current Trading. The statement confirms since the trading statement made on 11 May 2016, Melrose has continued to trade in line with the Melrose Board’s expectations.

BE

... Though as noted, Nortek's Nasdaq-listed so we have a bit of valuation work pre deal.

11:35 am
BE

This is from Jefferies post the numbers in mid May.

BE

Security shows good momentum. The security business showed continued strength
partially driven by new products which aim to make NTK a more complete solutions
provider. We do note, however, that first quarter sales were positively impacted by some
business pulled forward from 2Q. Therefore, we would expect to see a deceleration in sales
growth, as well as a negative impact to margin in 2Q.

BE

HVAC off to a slow start in 2Q, but operating issues no longer lingering. Robust
growth in HVAC in the first quarter was aided by an exceptionally easy comp (1Q15: -23.7%
YOY); therefore, we do not expect this level of growth to continue throughout the remainder
of 2016. Management also noted that the cooling season was off to a slow start given
mild weather, but the segment should benefit as the operating issues are now behind the
company. We would expect to see margins return toward 2014 levels, with 2Q being a
strong indicator as it is typically is the highest margin period.

11:36 am
BE

CAS expected to improve over the course of the year. We would expect to see
margin improvement to continue given restructuring actions and the benefit from operating
efficiencies as the company works through the learning curve associated with the products
transferred last year. Lastly, backlog declined by 1% sequentially, as the business was
negatively impacted by the loss of sales from a large customer; however, the YOY impact
was dampened by increased bookings from the data center and clean room applications.
Therefore, we would expect to see a similar offset flow through revenues during the rest
of 2016.

BE

AQH product refresh driving growth in 2016. The roll out of new products should
help the business outperform the residential repair and remodel market, which we expect
to grow in the mid-single digit range for 2016. Additionally, the new products are expected
to provide a margin tailwind after product transition costs are absorbed.

BE

NTK is trading at 7.0x 2016E EV/EBITDA, a discount to the group. Our $54 PT is based on
60% weighting off our 2016 EBITDA estimate using a 7.0x multiple and 40% weighting off
of mid-cycle EBITDA using a 5.8x multiple. Risks to our price target include execution risk,
R&R activity, and working capital discipline.

11:00 am
PM

Welcome to sterling gets flushed down the toilet, live

PM

Here's Melrose's own description of what it does, btw

PM

Melrose is engaged in a ''buy, improve, sell'' business model to create value for its shareholders. The Company's focus is to acquire high quality industrial manufacturing businesses with strong fundamentals whose performance can benefit from a change in circumstances. The strategy is based on supporting and incentivising management teams to transform and grow their businesses without the burden of quarterly reporting or restrictive financing covenants, achieving above market profit growth and increased operating margins. Through a combination of overhead reduction and gross margin expansion, achieved through targeted investment in portfolio businesses, Melrose has been able to increase headline(3) operating margins by five to nine percentage points in all historical investments. Melrose employs low levels of leverage but invests heavily in its businesses. On average, Melrose invests a further third of the original equity purchase price in its businesses post-acquisition.

11:45 am
BE

David McCarthy's the analyst here.

PM

Yeah, but price war feel inevitable now -- shoppers feeling distinctly poorer

BE

Potential for a major price initiative: The CEO of Wal-Mart International (not listed) stated recently that ASDA will prioritise sales over margin. We believe this suggests ASDA may be preparing a major price repositioning. If ASDA does reposition fundamentally, then it could seriously damage sector profitability. Consequently, we think it prudent to downgrade our ratings on Tesco and Morrison to reflect our growing concern. Inside we look at what ASDA could do, how it would impact industry profits, and how it would influence long-term industry structure.

Why now: ASDA has learnt if it prioritises margins, it will lose its sales, which then leads to a falling margin. Better a company invests its margin to reward its customers and to protect its sales than to see margins eroded by the competition. ASDA has endured seven consecutive quarters of LFL sales declines, giving a two-year decline of c10%. Based on the CEO's comments, we believe ASDA wants to regain price leadership and to send a message to the discounters of what to expect in the US.

Signals: We think it is significant the comments were made to shareholders and not to the press, and that they were made by the Head of Wal-Mart International, not the CEO of ASDA, who has now stepped down. If ASDA does nothing now, and sales continue to decline, International management would lose credibility.

How much: ASDA had been the UK's most profitable retailer with a c5% operating margin. Although recent data suggest some margin erosion, we believe ASDA still has the highest operating margin of the Big 4 and possibly a higher one than the discounters. If ASDA decided to invest half its margin into price, a competitor reaction could wipe out almost all industry profitability and would force an industry restructure.

The great unknown: For now, we are trying to second guess ASDA. Any move would have to be significant, in our view, and to a degree that the competition cannot match. Therefore we believe ASDA may invest half its margin, or more into price. A summer move is the most likely timescale and if ASDA has not price repositioned by then, the immediate risk would recede.

Conclusion: With such uncertainty, we downgrade Tesco (TSCO LN, 178p) to Hold from Buy with a new TP of 195p from 240p, Morrison (MRW LN, 188p) to Reduce from Hold with a new TP of 135p from 165p, and reiterate Sainsbury (SBRY LN, 231p) at Reduce with a new TP of 165p from 175p. Our target price changes are mainly due to beta-driven changes in the risk premium.

11:46 am
BE

And, yeah, we have been dull about this for quite a while. Such as here: https://next.ft.co...-8ba3-cdd781d02d89

BE

Back to HSBC.

BE

If a frog is dropped into a bowl of hot water, it hops out. But if a frog is dropped in a bowl of warm water and that water is gently warmed up, then by the time the frog knows it is time to get out, it no longer has the strength to do so and ultimately perishes.

11:47 am
BE

None of the supermarkets mentioned in the research sell live frogs, to be clear.

BE

This situation has described UK food retailing for the best part of the last decade. The
majors became complacent and did not take account of the environment (struggling consumers and expanding discounters). Most competitive moves by the majors have been quite small and have been easily matched sooner or later, resulting in little change to comparative positions but with a reduction in industry profitability.
For these reasons we argued for many years that the industry needed a “Black Friday” (or a “Tesco Tuesday”) in order to create a loser on which the rest of the industry could feed. We had advocated, when Tesco had a much higher margin, that it should fundamentally reposition on price to such an extent that the competition could not follow. When Tesco’s UK operating margin was substantially ahead of the competition, this was possible, but now with Tesco
having the lowest margin of the Big 4, it is harder for it to do. It appears ASDA is the company now best positioned to undertake this strategy.

BE

ASDA had and probably still has the largest operating margin of the Big 4 and has the fire
power to undertake the repositioning that we talk about. Plus it has a big brother in Wal-Mart that could support it directly in a battle with the discounters in the UK, or indirectly by calling for regional support from some of its large multi-national suppliers.

11:48 am
BE

With a c5% operating margin, ASDA could take a radical decision to invest most of this into
price, knowing that the competition could not match them. For demonstrative purposes we run a scenario where ASDA invests 3% into price. This is a very sizeable investment and would be greater than anything seen in the UK for decades. We do not know what ASDA plans (if anything) but we use 3% to demonstrate the devastating impact such an investment could have on the industry. The following table below shows how ASDA’s margin and a 3% reduction would compare to the operating margins of the leading competition. We estimate Tesco, Sainsbury and Morrison could fall into losses if they matched ASDA on this scenario.

BE

Sandy Chen at Cenkos is a seller of Lloyds.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 50.02, down 1 (-1.96%), High: 51.39, Low: 49.81, Volume: 127.36m
BE

With probably-PM Theresa May probably looking to delay triggering Brexit for as long as possible, the lack of macro clarity could extend into 2017 – thus providing little support for GBP.

This is already having a direct and lasting negative impact on the economy. A clear example is the commercial property market, where three funds (and counting) have imposed gating restrictions on redemptions so that they can sell parts of their existing portfolios to generate the cash to pay off their (lucky) current swathe of redemptions.

But the challenges are (1) the commercial property market is a classic illiquid market, where a wave of sellers will rip the bottom out of prices, and (2) as the BOE itself pointed out, overseas buyers accounted for half of commercial property transactions since 2013, and in 1Q16 the volume of transactions involving foreign investors had halved quarter-on-quarter. With GBP now plumbing 31-year lows, it would be understandable if this overseas half of the market decides to sit on the sidelines for a while.

Amongst the UK banks, this will hurt Lloyds and RBS particularly badly; both have large commercial property loan portfolios, and the coming falls in commercial property price indices will translate into higher required impairment provisions against them. And to kill off any remaining Lloyds dividend bulls, BOE governor Carney explicitly ruled out using any of the capital headroom from yesterday’s cut in the countercyclical capital buffer to pay a higher dividend.

So we reiterate our Sells on LLOY and RBS; this may carry on for quite a while.

11:58 am
BE

Macquarie is a buyer of Lloyds.

BE

Residential property yields (estimated 4.0%) remain well above 2007 lows,
whilst average Commercial Real Estate yields of 5.8% look far from
demanding in the current interest rate environment.

BE

Action and recommendation

 Lloyds share price has collapsed -26% since the Brexit vote, more than twice
our -11% revision to 2017 earnings estimate.

 This leaves the shares trading on PTBV16e of 0.9x. This looks extreme for a
UK focused Retail & commercial banking operation, that generated an
adjusted ROTE 2015 of 16% and which we conservatively estimate can
generate a sustainable ROTE of 12% through the cycle.

 The market is clearly concerned by the outlook for UK property. This is highly
relevant for Lloyds given 66% of their loan book (net £301bn) is UK secured
residential exposure.

 However with little mortgage lending growth in recent years, UK interest rates
set to fall from here and a current average loan to value of only 46%, we
remain comfortable on the mortgage credit outlook.

 We also estimate that they have c£19bn (c3% of lending) of exposure to UK
Commercial Real Estate (CRE). Whilst there are clearly concerns with prime
London property, average UK CRE rental yields are currently just short of 6%,
which is far from demanding in the current rate environment.

 We also note that c80% of the Lloyds exposure is at LTVs of less than 70%,
which provides added comfort.

11:59 am
BE

............. And of RBS.

BE

 RBS management have our sympathy. Seven years of hard work broadly
doing the right thing – simplifying the Group, cutting back the Non-core,
focusing on Retail & commercial banking, de-risking portfolios (CRE exposure
£28bn against £97bn in 2008 – and c70% greater than 80% LTV) – and the market
broadly prices the shares back to 2009 levels when the company was
insolvent (see Fig 2).

 Significant litigation liabilities? Sure, but we have US RMBS pencilled in at
$10bn and still reach a 200p fair value. Forecast 2016e CET1 of 16% implies
£7bn ($9bn) of surplus equity (to 13%) even before factoring in potential Pillar
2 relief.

 Williams & Glynn disposal? A complete debacle, but still only 10% of Group
profits.

 Recent weakness leaves the shares on PTBV16e 0.45x. For a business that
has undertaken 7 years of balance sheet de-risking and will ultimately be
simple Retail & commercial banking operation not dis-similar to Lloyds – this
is too cheap, in our view. Upgrade to Outperform.

BE

Growth premiums associated with the speciality/challengers banks have
materially eroded since the Brexit vote on the 23rd of June. We continue to rate
Aldermore (Fair Value: 235p), Shawbrook (Fair Value: 305p), Virgin Money (Fair
value: 350p) and Clydesdale (Fair Value: 240p) as Outperform. Share prices
deterioration since Brexit (23rd of June) for these stocks are materially higher
than peers (down -45% for ALD and SHAW and -30% for VM). We upgrade OSB
(Fair Value: 270p) to Outperform as the share price today reflects a scenario for
UK Buy to Let (BLT) which we don’t see as likely to materialise given c60%
remortgage activity and expected monetary support from the Bank of England.

12:03 pm
BE

The UK decision to leave the EU is likely to lead to a sluggish economic
environment which could lead to slower overall loan origination volumes for the
sector, increase pressures on asset margins from a likely easing of monetary
policy by the BOE and a possibility for credit impairments to rise from current
cyclical lows. Macquarie have reduced GDP growth expectations for the UK and
are now assuming limited growth in H2 2016 (equating to +1.7% for the year),
falling to +1.1% for 2017. We have also made very modest reductions (-0.2%) to
Euro area economic growth expectations for both 2016 and 2017.

BE

We halve the expected overall level of loan growth for the speciality bank
sector. We note that even during the 2008/09 period post the recent crisis,
growth rates for secured lending did not go negative. We do not believe we
are entering a period anything similar to the last crisis, while the capital levels
of the banking sector are far superior in quantity and quality today than while
entering the 2007/08 crisis.

BE

We assume further monetary easing by the BOE is likely to reduce margins
for the sector. We assume a 20bps-50bps deterioration of sector margins over
the next two years.
 We assume a normalisation of impairment levels from the current cyclical
lows. We do not expect impairments levels to reach anywhere like the peak of
2009/10 given the continued easy monetary policy in the UK.

12:04 pm
BE

Sustainable levels of ROE
Our assumptions reduce sustainable levels of ROTE for the sector from the
current mid-twenties to mid-teens by 2018e. We reflect this in our valuations.

BE

EPS estimates fall on median 5% for FY16e, 15% for FY17e and 23% for
FY18e. Banks with current low levels of EPS and ROTE or those that depend on
future growth to right-size current ROTE levels see material impact to EPS levels
vs. peers.

BE

We leave ratings for Paragon unchanged but reduce Fair value to reflect
changes to estimates: Paragon (Neutral; Fair Value: 260p);
